No more scuba diving certifications or equipment rentals: With the ability to breathe underwater without any gear, people would no longer need to invest time and money in obtaining scuba diving certifications or renting expensive equipment. This would open up the ocean and other bodies of water to a wider range of people, making it more accessible and enjoyable for everyone.

Increased ocean exploration and tourism: With the ability to breathe underwater, people would be able to explore the ocean and its many wonders without any limitations. This would lead to a surge in ocean-based tourism, as people would be able to experience the beauty and diversity of marine life up close and personal.

Enhanced marine conservation efforts: Being able to breathe underwater would allow people to spend more time observing and studying marine ecosystems, leading to a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between marine life and their environments. This increased knowledge would enable more effective conservation efforts, as people would be able to identify and address the root causes of marine degradation and depletion.

New forms of underwater communication and commerce: With the ability to breathe underwater, people would be able to communicate and conduct business in a completely new way. This could lead to the development of new languages and forms of communication, as well as new forms of commerce and trade that take advantage of the unique properties of underwater environments.

Changes in medical research and treatment: The ability to breathe underwater could lead to new insights into the workings of the human body, particularly in relation to the effects of pressure and gas composition on the body. This could lead to new treatments and therapies for a range of medical conditions, as well as a better understanding of the effects of underwater environments on human health.
